questions.text: At what vertebral level is the lower border of the pharynx?
questions.solution:
The lower border of the pharynx is at the level of the sixth or seventh cervical vertebrae.

The pharynx extends from the cranial base to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (at the level of the sixth or seventh cervical vertebra). It is divided into the nasopharynx, oropharynx, and laryngopharynx.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident performing endoscopy of the nasopharynx in a patient with suspected nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Which of the following structures would you not expect to find here?
questions.solution:
Piriform fossa is a structure present in the laryngopharynx and not the nasopharynx.

The nasopharynx is present above the soft palate and is made up of the roof, floor, posterior wall, and two lateral walls. Important structures seen in the nasopharynx are:

  • Pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube
  • Torus tubarius- tubal elevation which is present behind the opening of the eustachian tube.
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller- A lateral pharyngeal recess that is present behind the torus tubarius. It is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma 
  • Pharyngeal tonsil which is present in the roof and posterior wall
  • Passavant's ridge.

The piriform fossa is occasionally, unnaturally deepened by smugglers using lead balls to conceal valuable materials like diamonds. Because of this, it is also referred to as 'smuggler's fossa'.

questions.text: Which of the following structures forms the Passavant's ridge?

choices.text: Levator veli palatini and superior constrictor

questions.solution:
Passavant's ridge is formed by palatopharyngeus and superior constrictor muscles.

Some fibers of the palatopharyngeus muscle pass deep to the mucous membrane of the pharynx and form an internal sphincter to the superior constrictor. These muscles contract and cause a ridge on the posterior wall of the nasopharynx which is known as Passavant's ridge.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl with pharyngitis complains of pain and blocked sensation in her right ear. Where does the involved structure open in the nasopharynx?

choices.text: Behind posterior end of inferior turbinate

questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a middle ear infection i.e., otitis media as a complication of pharyngitis. This is due to the spread of the infection via the eustachian tube. It opens approximately behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate, in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx.

The eustachian tube connects the nasopharynx and the tympanic cavity in the middle ear. It is usually collapsed and opens during activities such as yawning or swallowing. Its function is to maintain the pressure in the middle ear cavity and drain any secretions from the middle ear.

questions.text: The following image shows the oropharynx in a 16-year-old girl who came with complaints of a sore throat and fever. Which of the following structures will you not see in this region?
questions.solution:
The given image shows purulent inflammation of the tonsils and the case scenario is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. Passavant's ridge is not seen in the oropharynx as it is present on the posterior wall of the nasopharynx. 

The oropharynx extends from below the soft palate to the upper border of the epiglottis. 

Structures seen in the oropharynx:

  • Palatoglossal folds
  • Palatopharyngeal folds
  • Palatine tonsils - between the palatoglossal and palatopharyngeal folds
  • Lingual tonsils
  • Valleculae - mucosal pouches between the tongue and the epiglottis.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident performing indirect laryngoscopy to visualize the hypopharynx in a patient with suspected glottic carcinoma. Which of the following structures will you not see here?
questions.solution:
Valleculae will not be seen here as they are a part of the oropharynx.

Hypopharynx/Laryngopharynx: 

  • It extends from the superior border of the epiglottis to the inferior border of the cricoid cartilage. 
  • It is separated from the oropharynx by the lateral glossoepiglottic folds.
  • The anterior wall is made by the parts of the laryngeal inlet, and posterior surfaces of the arytenoid and cricoid cartilages. 

Pyriform fossae are present between the aryepiglottic folds medially and thyroid cartilage, thyrohyoid membrane laterally. They serve as channels that direct the solid and liquid food from the oral cavity into the esophagus.

Clinical significance: Branches of the internal laryngeal nerve lie beneath the mucous membrane of the piriform fossa. Hence this site can be used for infiltrating the local anesthetics.

questions.text: Where is the sinus of Morgagni present?

choices.text: Between middle constrictor and inferior constrictor
Between superior constrictor and middle constrictor

questions.solution:
Sinus of Morgagni is a gap present between the base of the skull and the upper border of superior constrictor muscle.

Structures passing through the sinus of Morgagni are as follows:

  • Palatine branch of ascending pharyngeal artery
  • Ascending palatine artery
  • Levator veli palatini muscle
  • Eustachian tube

Note: Sinus of Morgagni syndrome/Trotter's triad is seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma which spreads laterally to involve the sinus of Morgagni. It is characterized by:

  • Conductive hearing loss
  • Ipsilateral immobility of the palate
  • Neuralgic pain.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with dysphagia and regurgitation. Barium swallow showed the following picture. Weakness of which of the following muscles predisposes to the given condition​?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with a pulsion diverticulum on the barium swallow is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. It originates through Killian's dehiscence, which is a site of weakness present in the inferior constrictor muscle.

The inferior constrictor muscle is made up of 2 parts:

  1. Upper part - thyropharyngeus, made of oblique fibres.
  2. Lower part - cricopharyngeus, made of transverse fibres.

Between the two muscles, there is a potential gap which is called the pharyngeal dimple or Killian's dehiscence.

Another site of weakness in the pharyngeal wall is the Laimer's triangle, which is present between the cricopharyngeus and the longitudinal muscle of the oesophagus.

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the pharyngeal plexus?
questions.solution:
Stylopharyngeus is not supplied by the pharyngeal plexus. It is supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

The pharyngeal plexus is formed by the pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve with contributions from the superior cervical sympathetic ganglion. It supplies:

  • All muscles of the soft palate 
    • Except tensor veli palatini - supplied by the mandibular nerve
  • All the muscles of the pharynx
    • Except stylopharyngeus - supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve.
